Lacrosse Recruitment
BY STEV EN EISENBERG
He came to Hopkins as a
lacrosse recruit. His SAT scores
were 380V and 390M. When he
spoke to Coach Henry Ciccarone
about his schedule the summer

intended to enroll in the usual
pre-med track. But Ciccarone
felt he would not be able to
compete with the brighter students and told him not to pursue

ignoring the coach's advice,
registered for the courses.
Four years later, the same

teams. Ile applied to medical
school but was repcted. Instead, he decided to go to the

after which he again applied to
medical school and was finally
accepted. He will be beginning
next fall.

Hopkins with scores of 390V
and 580M while being ranked in
the top third of his high school
class. He successfully graduated
with a political economy degree
and is now a trainee in an
executive training program with
Macy's of New York.

few questions concerning the

It's 1992, and as I look back over the past two
decades as President, I feel a warm sense of accomplishment. Hopkins has come a long was since '72 when it
was a little two-campus school with only Baltimore

The early growth (Peabody, SAIS, APL) put
Hopkins in the Ivy League League and made a strong
foundation for the extensive work of the past decade.
The expansion of the East Baltimore campus to include

almost doubled the revenues from that campus. Admission is highly selective, of course, but tuition is
535,000/year. I am quite pleased that after only seven

the training of acupuncturists and faith healers in the
country.
1982 saw Hopkins make a giant step from an

it necessary that Hopkins get larger, until one day (I
estimate 1998) I expect they will converge and Hopkins will he synonymous with world education. Some
of the exchange campuses 1 have established include:
Nanjing, China; Brazilia, Brazil; Hamburg, Germany;
